title: Erdős Problem #174
description: Characterize the Ramsey sets in Euclidean space—finite configurations that always contain monochromatic copies under any coloring.

meta.author: Erdős, Graham, Montgomery, Rothschild, Spencer, Straus

overview.historicalContext: Euclidean Ramsey theory was founded by Erdős, Graham, Montgomery, Rothschild, Spencer, and Straus in 1973. The theory asks which geometric configurations have the Ramsey property: no matter how you color high-dimensional space, you can always find a monochromatic copy. This extends classical combinatorial Ramsey theory into the geometric realm.
overview.problemStatement: A finite set A ⊂ ℝⁿ is called Ramsey if, for any k ≥ 1, there exists d = d(A,k) such that in any k-coloring of ℝᵈ there exists a monochromatic congruent copy of A. Characterize the Ramsey sets in ℝⁿ.
overview.proofStrategy: The necessary condition (spherical) is proved via a contrapositive argument using distance-based colorings. The sufficient direction (characterizing which spherical sets are Ramsey) remains open, with Graham's conjecture and the Leader-Russell-Walters subtransitivity conjecture as the main candidates.
keyInsights: Every Ramsey set must be spherical—lie on the surface of some sphere
Known Ramsey families: rectangles, simplices, trapezoids, regular polygons
The characterization problem cannot be resolved by finite computation

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #174 is OPEN. The necessary condition (spherical) is known, but the complete characterization of Ramsey sets remains elusive. Graham's conjecture and the LRW subtransitivity conjecture represent the two main candidate characterizations.
conclusion.implications: A resolution would unify the known Ramsey constructions and potentially yield new algebraic or geometric criteria for the Ramsey property. It connects Ramsey theory, group actions, and Euclidean geometry.
openQuestions: Is every spherical set Ramsey? (Graham's conjecture)
Does subtransitivity characterize Ramsey sets? (LRW conjecture)
What are optimal dimension bounds d(A,k) for specific configurations?
